Specific Details: Pilot Town For Retail - Tralee
DPOs Lobbied: Damien English|Minister of State|Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment::Norma Foley|Minister|Department of Education::Brendan Griffin|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Leo Varadkar|An Tánaiste|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Pilot Town For Retail - Tralee
Intended Results: We are seeking your support to utilise Tralee as a National Pilot Town to understand and address how retail can adapt to a new landscape. We are also seeking your support to examine holistically how our urban areas and businesses can adapt to embrace a new era in retailing, how we can consolidate and grow local family-owned and international retail side by side in both a town centre and edge of town setting which Tralee has both and how our town can sustainably support the growth of retail.::With your support we want to become a testbed for retail development as a 'live town' test case that works with all stakeholders, business owners, planners, retail and technology experts to embrace change, develop technology and new retail experiences, we know Tralee as a Pilot Town can forge out key learnings, develop solutions, create employment and then help this to be applied to all urban areas in Ireland::Funding for a pilot retail programme in Tralee

I measc na mórcheisteanna atá ag déanamh go leor imní dúinn agus do na scoileanna ná na nithe thíos agus ba mhór againn an deis iad a phlé leat:
1. Gaeilge na hArdteiste agus an comhairliúchán idir lámha
2. Caighdeán agus soláthar mhúinteoirí atá inniúil don chóras lán-Ghaeilge / Gaeltachta ag an dá leibhéal
3. Próiseas bunaithe scoile, agus ceist na nAonad ach go háirithe.
An dara iarratas a bhaineann leis an litir seo ná filleadh ar an gcuireadh a chuireamar chugat le linn mhí an Mheithimh labhairt ag ár gcomhdháil oideachais atá dírithe ar riachtanais oiliúna agus forbartha na scoileanna lán-Ghaeilge agus Gaeltachta uile sa tír. Specific Details: We continued to lobby the Ministers for Education and Special Education, in addition to local representatives and Education Stakeholders in relation to Principal Workload, sub crisis & SEN provisions in our schools. We welcomed Minsiter Joesphas Madigan's annoucement that the ESPEN Act will be reviewed and sought to be included as school leaders in the consultation process. We also queried if and how our schools are being re-profiled by the NCSE for the purposes of SEN, SET and SNA allocations.
DPOs Lobbied: Norma Foley|Minister|Department of Education::Josepha Madigan|Minister of State|Department of Education
Subject Matter: We continued to lobby the Ministers for Education and Special Education, in addition to local representatives and Education Stakeholders in relation to Principal Workload, sub crisis & SEN provisions in our schools. We welcomed Minsiter Joesphas Madigan's annoucement that the ESPEN Act will be reviewed and sought to be included as school leaders in the consultation process. We also queried if and how our schools are being re-profiled by the NCSE for the purposes of SEN, SET and SNA allocations.
Intended Results: To secure greater supports for principal teachers and pupils with SEN,  and to secure transparency and clarity in relation to NCSE and DoE profiling our schools.
Lobbying Activities: We emailed principal teachers to complete brief surveys in relation to substitution and attendance in their schools, in order to provide data to the education stakeholders attesting to the need for greater and continued supports for schools in terms of cover for absences, availability of substitute teachers and snas, and also the need for banked hours to be restored in order to prevent pupils with SEN from continuing to be detrimentally impacted by the sub crisis. We highlighted the results of these surveys on social media and in emails to education stakeholders and Ministers.|Email|100+

Specific Details: We continued to lobby the Ministers for Education and Special Education, in addition to local representatives and Education Stakeholders in relation to Principal Workload & SEN(Special Education Needs) provisions in our schools. We continue to seek a full review of EPSEN (Education of Persons with Special Education Needs)Act 2004 and ask for meaningful and timely consultation with school leaders.
DPOs Lobbied: Norma Foley|Minister|Department of Education::Josepha Madigan|Minister of State|Department of Education
Subject Matter: We continued to lobby the Ministers for Education and Special Education, in addition to local representatives and Education Stakeholders in relation to Principal Workload & SEN(Special Education Needs) provisions in our schools. We continue to seek a full review of EPSEN (Education of Persons with Special Education Needs)Act 2004 and ask for meaningful and timely consultation with school leaders.
Intended Results: A change in the POD (Pupil Online Database) system which would include a mechanism for communicating our exact SEN (Special Education Needs) school profiles to the Department of Education and the NCSE (National Council for Special Education) thereby ensuring that our schools are accurately profiled for the purposes of providing sufficient SET (Special Education Teaching)hours and SNA (Special Needs Assistant) access to our SEN (Special Education Needs) pupils.::To secure a meeting with the Minister for Education to discuss these issues.
Lobbying Activities: Emails were sent to practicing primary school principals to seek current information in relation to SET (Special Education Teacher) allocations. A link to an online app which assists principals in finding schools to cluster SET hours with was also shared, as was an app which allowed schools to compare 2022 SET allocations with previous years allocations. The results of this was shared on social media to raise awareness and continue to highlight the shortfalls in SEN provisions for our schools and pupils.|Email|2-5

Specific Details: We lobbied government Ministers and Education Stakeholders in relation to three issues: 1) The rescinding of substitution cover for certain approved teacher leave, 2) the NCSE foisting their new legislative responsibilities for AON (Assessment of Need) onto school principals and 3) the review of the EPSEN ACT.
DPOs Lobbied: Norma Foley|Minister|Department of Education::Josepha Madigan|Minister of State|Department of Education
Subject Matter: We lobbied government Ministers and Education Stakeholders in relation to three issues: 1) The rescinding of substitution cover for certain approved teacher leave, 2) the NCSE foisting their new legislative responsibilities for AON (Assessment of Need) onto school principals and 3) the review of the EPSEN ACT.
Intended Results: We wished to highlight the impact of these issues on schools and pupils, we sought to reverse the rescinding of substitution cover for teacher approved leave as children are regularly missing out on having a teacher to cover their class (most especially pupils with additional needs), placing pressure on schools and pupils. We objected to the foisting of AON responsibilities on school principals & questioned the potential litigation, & we sought consultation in the EPSEN review.
Current or Former DPOs: Michael Lowry|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Mattie McGrath|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Grassroots directive: Email the Minister and Education Stakeholders, and also local representatives with our statement or your own letter and ask them to be aware of its contents and respond accordingly.

Specific Details: Shortage of Gardai in Kerry
Subject Matter: Shortage of Gardai in Kerry
Intended Results: Following a recent meeting with Gardai here in Tralee, it was highlighted the numbers currently serving here in the capital and across the county, while there has been a change to community policing, the numbers here in Tralee are just not enough. On October 31st between the hours of 6pm and 3am, Tralee had 3 times the number of callouts of other Kerry towns, during this time there were 4 gardai on duty, this is simply not good enough.::Tralee Chamber would like Minister Norma Foley to raise these questions with her colleagues in Government and the Department of Justice on behalf of Tralee Chamber. (1) What the Chamber is asking for is a review of the current numbers of Gardai serving? (2) What can be done to make the process for joining the guards more attractive and fluid, the numbers coming out of Templemore are dropping each year with also large numbers of gardai retiring. (3) A full review of policing standards in Ireland.
Lobbying Activities: Email sent to Minister Norma Foley on Wednesday 14th December 2022.|Email|1

Specific Details: Advocated for formal accommodations in the Reasonable Accommodations at the Certificate Examinations (RACE) for secondary school students who stammer
Subject Matter: Advocated for formal accommodations in the Reasonable Accommodations at the Certificate Examinations (RACE) for secondary school students who stammer
Intended Results:
In Junior Cert and Leaving Cert oral exam components, there are no official provisions or RACE guidelines to support secondary school students who stammer. Without appropriate accommodations, students who stammer are at a disadvantages compared to their peers.  
The ISA are advocating for the State Examinations Commission (SEC) to update the 2025 RACE guidelines to include accommodations for students who stammer such as extra time and an informed approach from examiners.
Lobbying Activities:
Email Subject: Advocating for Accommodations for Students Who Stammer in Oral Exams

Email highlighting the current absence of 'stammering' as an additional need in the SEC RACE Guidelines.  |Email|1
